questiontext.text:
A projectile is released at an angle $$\theta$$ of  45 degrees from horizontal at an initial velocity (VI) of  33 m/s, as per the image below.

What is the maximum height (h), that the projectile reaches?

{1:NUMERICAL:=27.8:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

What is the horizontal range (R) that the projectile will travel before hitting the ground?

{1:NUMERICAL:=111.1:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Give your answers in metres correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
Looking at the y component first, and using the knowledge that the vertical velocity is zero at the maximum height:

t = (v-u)/a = (0 - (33 x sin(45)) / -9.8) =  2.4 seconds.

h = (u*t) + (0.5*a*t2) =  (23.3 x  2.4) - (4.9 x  22) =  27.8 metres.

Looking at the x component, and using the knowledge that the horizontal acceleration is zero:

R = (2*u*t) = (2 x cos(45 x  2.4)) =  111.1 metres.

hint.text: Use the SUVAT equations of motion on both the x and y components of the projectile's motion to solve this question.

A projectile is released at an angle $$\theta$$ of  60 degrees from horizontal at an initial velocity (VI) of  58 m/s, as per the image below.

What is the maximum height (h), that the projectile reaches?

{1:NUMERICAL:=128.7:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

What is the horizontal range (R) that the projectile will travel before hitting the ground?

{1:NUMERICAL:=297.3:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

(Give your answers in metres correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #86).

generalfeedback.text:
Looking at the y component first, and using the knowledge that the vertical velocity is zero at the maximum height:

t = (v-u)/a = (0 - (58 x sin(60)) / -9.8) =  5.1 seconds.

h = (u*t) + (0.5*a*t2) =  (50.2 x  5.1) - (4.9 x  52) =  128.7 metres.

Looking at the x component, and using the knowledge that the horizontal acceleration is zero:

R = (2*u*t) = (2 x cos(60 x  5.1)) =  297.3 metres.
